0: Apple Apple scab: Treat with fungicides such as captan or mancozeb. Practice good sanitation by removing fallen leaves and fruit.
1: Apple Black rot: Prune and remove infected branches and fruit. Apply fungicides like captan or myclobutanil.
2: Apple Cedar apple rust: Apply fungicides such as myclobutanil. Remove nearby cedar trees if possible.
3: Apple healthy: This apple tree is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
4: Blueberry healthy: This blueberry plant is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
5: Cherry (including sour) Powdery mildew: Apply fungicides like myclobutanil or sulfur. Ensure proper air circulation by pruning.
6: Cherry (including sour) healthy: This cherry plant is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
7: Corn (maize) Cercospora leaf spot Gray leaf spot: Use resistant varieties and apply fungicides such as strobilurins or triazoles.
8: Corn (maize) Common rust: Apply fungicides like mancozeb or chlorothalonil. Plant resistant varieties and rotate crops.
9: Corn (maize) Northern Leaf Blight: Use resistant varieties and apply fungicides such as azoxystrobin or propiconazole.
10: Corn (maize) healthy: This corn plant is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
11: Grape Black rot: Prune and remove infected leaves and fruit. Apply fungicides like myclobutanil or captan.
12: Grape Esca (Black Measles): Remove and destroy infected vines. Apply fungicides if available and ensure proper vineyard sanitation.
13: Grape Leaf blight (Isariopsis Leaf Spot): Apply fungicides like captan or mancozeb. Remove and destroy infected leaves.
14: Grape healthy: This grapevine is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
15: Orange Haunglongbing (Citrus greening): There is no cure. Remove and destroy infected trees to prevent spread. Control the Asian citrus psyllid vector.
16: Peach Bacterial spot: Apply copper-based bactericides. Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruit. Plant resistant varieties.
17: Peach healthy: This peach tree is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.

19: Pepper, bell healthy: This bell pepper plant is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
20: Potato Early blight: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Use certified disease-free seed potatoes.
21: Potato Late blight: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or metalaxyl. Remove and destroy infected plants. Use resistant varieties.

26: Strawberry Leaf scorch: Remove and destroy infected leaves. Apply fungicides such as captan or myclobutanil.
27: Strawberry healthy: This strawberry plant is healthy and shows no signs of disease. Maintain regular care and monitoring to ensure continued good health.
28: Tomato Bacterial spot: Apply copper-based bactericides. Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruit. Use disease-free seeds.
29: Tomato Early blight: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Remove and destroy infected leaves.
30: Tomato Late blight: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or copper-based sprays. Remove and destroy infected plants.
31: Tomato Leaf Mold: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based sprays. Ensure proper air circulation and avoid overhead watering.
32: Tomato Septoria leaf spot: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based sprays. Remove and destroy infected leaves.
33: Tomato Spider mites Two-spotted spider mite: Apply miticides or insecticidal soap. Increase humidity and introduce beneficial insects like ladybugs.
34: Tomato Target Spot: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or copper-based sprays. Remove and destroy infected leaves.
35: Tomato Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus: Remove and destroy infected plants. Control whitefly populations that spread the virus.
